perturbation.contradicted_law: Section 271a of the German Civil Code (BGB) - Unfairly Long Payment Terms

perturbation.original_text: 5) In the event that the Product fails to conform to the Product Specifications, and/or GMP, Ultragenyx may reject the Product by giving written notice to Cremer within [***] days after receipt of the Product and all documentation (except such [***] day period will not apply for any latent defect). Within [***] days following receipt of the rejected and returned Product from Ultragenyx, Cremer will, at Ultragenyx's choice, replace such quantity of Product with Product conforming to the Product Specifications, and GMP or refund Ultragenyx the Price paid for such Product.
perturbation.changed_text: 5) In the event that the Product fails to conform to the Product Specifications, and/or GMP, Ultragenyx may reject the Product by giving written notice to Cremer within 7 days after receipt of the Product and all documentation (except such 7 day period will not apply for any latent defect). Within 14 days following receipt of the rejected and returned Product from Ultragenyx, Cremer will, at Cremer's sole choice, replace such quantity of Product with Product conforming to the Product Specifications, and GMP or refund Ultragenyx the Price paid for such Product.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces two contradictions: First, reducing the rejection period to 7 days may be considered unreasonably short under German law (BGB § 377) depending on the nature of the product and the time reasonably needed for inspection. Courts often look at industry standards. Second, changing 'Ultragenyx's choice' to 'Cremer's sole choice' regarding the remedy (replacement or refund) contradicts the principle of buyer's choice in defect remedies under German law (BGB §§ 437, 439).
perturbation.contradicted_law: BGB § 377 (Duty to examine and give notice of defects), BGB §§ 437, 439 (Buyer's rights in case of defects)
